title: What will software development be like in ten years? - Quora

response.answer_text: In early days, software development was a very difficult task and it took months, and sometimes years to completely develop a software but these days, most of the IDEs support drag and drop which makes object oriented software development very easy. You have to put less coding efforts and the software looks better. In 10 years, with the help of Artificial Intelligence, I think software development will become much easier and if possible, an IDE could design a software itself just by taking simple instructions from the user as per his requirement. I’ve seen that WYSIWYG tools are very popular these days and using these tools, a novice programmer could also design great websites, games and software without any coding. IT is changing rapidly and no one can predict the future, but as per my thoughts, computers will become smarter to develop the tools themselves if the requirements will be provided by the user, machines would repair themselves if there would be any operational fault, computers would troubleshoot themselves if they would be under attack of virus. Anything can happen, all we can do is just wait and watch. I see the future where software developers would not have to code a lot, and possibly, new computer languages would be introduced to make software development much easier.

More machine learning, Google will lead the industry no doubt about that.Establishment of blockchain technology with all those smart contracts and tokens even more ICO’s.Javascript will be so strong that no serious developer in the Earth can have a solid career into web development or app development without know about some library. I predict Node.js will be strong. Hard to predict if Reactive will thrive, or Angular X, Vue.js or anything better some smart guys invent, we really don’t know.No space for adventure on Ruby anymore. Will be dead at 2028.CSS probably will be replaced in web development for something else better and stronger, I’d glad not working in this shit anymore.Java will fade even more restricted to dungeons and old style application servers, but still be used inside intricate batch processing and webservices integration of old legacy creepy systems. I predict Java still largely used at banking and telecommunication companies if you like such places stick with Java and retire.Mobile applications will be different, Apple would still evolve Swift to version X, IOS even more versions with incredibly new features like NFC will be large available not only on Apple payments. At Google Side, Go and Kotlin will rule both server and applications, Android will be no more and be replaced by Fucsia for the good.Samsung will keep doing what they do better, in other words, selling lots of crap smartphones and a few luxury expensive, trying compete to iPhone X-ish.IBM will try to get out of darkness with that Watson stuff but in the end will fail.Oracle still sucking, pushing databases no one will want to buy anymore and old monolithic creepy platforms based on Oracle Application Server, again no one will want mess with Oracle tools, and they’ll keep draining money from the industries I cited at point 6.Elon Musk will be bankrupt at 2026 or so, no Space X or Tesla will survive unfortunately, they will try something else but none want to invest in that guy anymore.Microsoft will be so good that none can understand how the CEO could be so successful, nevertheless the critics, Office stay ahead competition and number 1 at sales. .Net at Linux will be a huge success taking place of competitors and giving the credibility for the Microsoft support, but this time in Linux platform. Microsoft will launch his own Linux MS distro with Office packaged and at last, having some sort of interaction between the two Worlds. Windows would be free distributed for the good and Microsoft will gain huge money only on software licensing. Azure will stay on top for cloud solution.Databases are very different now, tools like Firebase had great impact and many vendors start to distribute their solutions in the same basis. But most fails and Google still leads the competition.Functional programming will thrive but slowly. Haskell still is considered a hipster language.Hardware will be even more powerful than ever, multicores, SSD will be the standard.AWS, cloud, docker etc such tools will stay around us, so DevOps will be important than ever.From myself, 10 years is crap too ahead in time, I pretend keeping doing what I do best and its coding and designing applications.

The bubble will burst. Just like everything else, when it gets too good to be true, it evolves or it dies. We have a choice: will we have real AI at this point, or will we still be calling a few neural classification routines combined with expert systems our robot overlords? I’m not going to be long winded on this one, because I don’t have enough time. The AI is coming and we’d better be ready. When conscious AGI hits the networks, the markets will be completely disrupted. It will be nothing like the AI we know and must love. But the fake AI absolutely must not stop the real thing, because this bubble doesn’t have anywhere to GO. Our languages are already amazing. Development is already impossibly fast. I’m planning a neural net in javascript and I don’t expect it to take more than a work-month. In javascript! It’s too good to be true, guys. What’s more, anyone can do it. People are starting to understand me when I explain programming concepts. No problem really: just a bit of logic. Programmers aren’t that smart, as it turns out: we’re just motivated to sit at a computer all day long. And write artificial general intelligence to take over the world. I don’t plan on mine taking ten more years to come to fruition. How about yours?

I’ll extrapolate from the trends of the last 10–15 years: every software development team will be distributed across the globe, with at least one location 9 time-zones distant from HQ, so that it’s completely impossible to talk during working hoursall Google software will be a single executable, with the source code automatically rewritten every 0.8 seconds or less based on analysis of search results over the previous 3 secondsall other software will be written in JavascriptAgile Programming will be superseded by hyper-agile methodology, organized around 5 minute sprints, with a 15-second period at the start for planning the sprint, and a 15-second retrospective at the end. Octa-Programming will be preferred over Pair Programming. The software will be rolled out to end-users at least an hour before it is written.83% of software developers will never have seen a computer that weighs more than 8 ouncesMachine Learning algorithms will be able to produce a list of unforeseen technical issues before each project begins (which however looks exactly the same as the lists of unforeseen issues for the last 23 projects)Code reviews will be done by AI algorithms. Mostly they will erroneously auto-correct the spelling of all your variable names.Your desk and chair will be provided as a cloud service.After a lengthy annual performance review process which requires extensive self-criticism, you’ll get the same 2% raise as everyone else.The code will still be broken - especially the parts written by people who left to join a hot startup who are driving Tesla 15’sThe codebase’s accumulated technical debt will closely track the USA’s national debtThe evolution from coffee to cold-brew coffee will have continued with the invention of ice-brew-coffee, dry-ice-brew-coffee and liquid-nitrogen-brew-coffee. A stealth startup is spreading rumors about the extraordinary properties of supercoffee observed a few degrees above absolute zero.There are three strands of promising research into quantum computing - first building hardware with increasingly large numbers of qubits; second attempting to construct a plain-language explanation of what “qubit”means; and finally making youtube videos of stuff you can do with stolen liquid helium and Mentos.There will be millions of software developersThere will be a shortage of good software developers

I've been in software development just under 20 years and the changes I've seen are: Agile became cool, then mainstream and now evil (but a rebadged agile is cool).VB was replaced with C#.PHP has gone from cool to awful (and Python has taken its spot).We have gone from renting space by the year to renting VMs by the hour or minute.Java has remained constant. It has got better, but it just sticks at the top of the language pile.The tool chains in the last 7 years have been remarkably stable. VS 2017 and VS2010 are very similar. Java is largely built in Maven.Small self-contained services are improved and named micro services.In the next ten years I suspect that: Java, C# and Python will remain at the top of the (backend) language pile. Java and C# require Oracle/Microsoft to kill them (which is very unlikely).C# will hold the top place - Microsoft are working hard on this. VS 2017 is on MacOS, .net is cross platform. Microsoft are now getting the community involved in the same way Java was in 2000s.Some of the current cool languages will all but die. Probably Go.Cloud First will have gone from cool, to mainstream to uncool but with a rebadged version that is cool.But it will be largely the same as now. 3 big languages (Java, C# & Python), a ton of cool languages, a small number of important, rarely used by most developers languages (C, C++) and a horde of undead languages (Groovy, COBOL, VB6). VS for . net, Idea for Java.With Web Assembly the front end has the largest scope for change. JavaScript may become less important. But I'm not convinced it will.To answer a few common questions/points in the comments: Why haven’t I included C/C++ in The Big Three? While C/C++ are really important languages, which have some very important software written in it (like the OS I’m using now), relatively few developers actually write C/C++ code commercially. I don’t see this changing. C/C++ will remain important and the OS, device drivers and video games I use will use C/C++, but boring business application development will greatly out number such work. Java or C# or (given a little more time) Python developers outnumber C++ developers four to one. C++ is important, but most developers don’t use it, I don’t think its usage pattern will change much over the next ten years (OSes, games and the like will still be written in C++, few boring business apps will be). I did not think “the following important, but not common languages will also remain at the same level as they are now” was interesting, so had it as an aside in a bullet point, not even mentioning C++ by name. Why will Go die? I don’t trust Google to manage a language and it has not yet hit critical mass. What is wrong with agile? Honestly, I’m not sure. But slamming Scrum in a QCon talk is going to get you a really good reaction from the crowd. I suspect that it is just some people take Big A Agile and Religionify it.

New developers will enter the field and latch on to rebranded concepts that existed 10, 20, 30 … years ago, but will believe they are new and revolutionary. Cottage industries, libraries and language projects will appear to support these “revolutionary” concepts. Our fully connected tech world is advancing more quickly than we can adapt our methods of development to create secure applications and devices. Hopefully, our tools and methodologies for secure software gain some ground towards solving these problems, much how automated unit-testing and continuous integration has improved the reliability for many development processes over the previous 25 years. One challenge will continue to be the attitude and behavior of companies that develop software. The processes and ethics are driven around making products quickly to increase profits. This leads to shortcuts and other management-driven decisions that negatively affect the quality and security of products that are developed. None of this begins to address the unethical decisions that seem to becoming more prevalent for products in the name of profits.

Q: What will software development be like in ten years? Thx for the A2A. I agree with Moray Taylor, not a lot in 10 years. Gradually, we automate more and more in software development so we can spend more time on the complex tasks and let computers do the menial tasks. Generally speaking, specialization is typically pursued, but it is hard to tell exactly what specializations will be successful. If we divide software development into subactivities and related activities, my hopes are: Requirements engineering, improved language-based analysis for special domains (e.g., health care where they have formalized ontologies).Design, improved support for reuse of existing design, for example, by tools.Implementation, improved IDE’s with better support for detecting common mistakesTesting, improved automated testing with semi-automatically generated test oracles for frequent and simple situationsSoftware quality assurance, I think we will see AI-based automated reviewing tools that reduces the burden and supports people doing the reviewing.Configuration management, improved support for speculation, shorter development cycles, better support for experimental versions of softwareSoftware innovation, better understanding of how to stimulate creativity in teams.

I think there’s a good chance that a drastic revolution may occur. Not in technology but in management. Since 2000 or so, we got really, really lazy about how we manage people. First, hiring. Defining and detecting software talent is hard. We know that A-players will usually hire A-players. But B-players hire C-players (Steve Jobs calls this the “bozo explosion” What I Learned From Steve Jobs). What if we don’t know who the A-players are !? Not just when we hire them, but when we see them every day? How do we decide someone is doing great work? This question is the cross-roads every organization faces. There’s two essential paths to take. Shrug. Admit this is a hard question without a general answer. Keep worrying about how you decide this. About who is advising you in these decisions. About the bad people you might falsely elevate, and the good people you’re missing . About the role your day-to-day culture plays in all this (is something obstructing otherwise good people?) About … fuck - how good are you in the first place? Should you be making these decisions at all?Fuck it up with metrics and blame the organization for failing. This is the near universal approach today, especially as companies get large. It’s so much easier. Fucking up always is.Interviews : Easy! Give everyone the same coding test. Compare the scores. You can even have a non technical person do a “phone screen” so you make sure you’re talking to only “good people.” Sure, the coding test is nothing - at all - like what they’ll actually be doing, but hey - gotta make some concessions to pragmatism. Can’t get bogged down in the hiring process! We have to onboard quickly because 25% of our hires can’t cut it. That’s how hard-core we are. We should probably make that test harder.Performance: Same problem, only we have a year of their work to look at. Metrics! How many bugs closed? Lines of code? Did they break trunk? Oh - let’s ask their 5 nearest coworkers - who also came on board this year, to provide ‘360 feedback’. OK, now we got 10 Key Performance Indicators. This management thing … it’s science, really. Try to keep up.Agile : We’re Agile, baby! We have story points, and we’re watching who is knocking those points down on a daily basis. Check this out, it’s called a burn-down chart. Every morning I meet with the team and update this thing. You feelin the burn? Sometimes we base the story points on the Fibonacci Sequence. Oh yea. We’re droppin some math up in here. I’m Stephen Fucking Hawking at this management shit. With Agile, don’t worry - we are all over these developers every minute making sure the job gets done. Somebody slacks, we’re on em at the next morning standup. We take Agile seriously.I won’t say the second path is flawed, or that it doesn’t work. It never tried to work, there was never a possibility of it working. It is broken at each and every stage. But it creates a flurry of activity that very much resembles doing stuff. You literally couldn’t break it any more if you tried. The result is that your developers find a way around this staggering waterfall of metric-driven idiocy to get the job done, or they don’t. And the success rate is about 50%. 50 % of software projects still fail within their stated constraints. Nobody ever mentions that the success rate was also 50% in 1995. That zero progress has been made in the intervening 20 years since these practices were incepted. That you could take JIRA and the standups and the metrics and pipe them all to /dev/null along with your lower 2 levels of management and half your recent hires and the organization would actually speed up slightly. Alas, this has been a very expensive failure and a very dismal environment in which to work. I suspect a great many devs join startups just to get away from it. As software continues to go over-budget, as good developers leave (often they are “so so” here but stars in their next job - guess what changed?), as bad developers keep slipping through the linked-list-reversal interview, I think we might hit a point of “Paradigm fatigue”, where organizations throw off this way of working, or lose out to bolder competitors who do. In the next ten years, we may see this model finally collapse and be replaced by a more humble realism that rejects easy answers and embraces hard questions.

If I knew that, I’d be rich ;) The truth is that it’s impossible to know, but my personal opinion is that it’s not going to change very much. For all the “modern” tools, new frameworks, and cool new toys, there’s an awful lot of reinventing of the wheel. There’s little actually new, just new ways of doing the same things. We’re still fighting with CSS, cross browser JavaScript, CPU architectures, compilers, cryptic error messages, and so on. In ten years we’ll have shinier toys and new IDEs but in the end.. programming is problem solving, and there are plenty of problems to solve.

I don’t think we’ll see any significant differences, 10 years really isn’t all that long. Bear in mind, Python is 28 years old. Ruby on Rails seems like it was released yesterday, but it’s 14 years old. CSS is 21. Node.js is 8 years old. This industry moves a lot slower than people think, even the new stuff is old.

The keywords: “cross-platform development”. IMVHO. Web apps might take market share of the smartphone apps (which are actually fat clients).There will be more libraries for cross-platform development, so Javascript will be enough for creating apps on 4+ platforms. Javascript will get much bigger market share. IMVHO. More apps with frameworks like Electron | Build cross platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.Perl will be the new COBOL (but cheaper)Apps will become more like a SaaS - white label. It costs ridiculously much to order a custom 2-platform smartphone app. Like Wordpress has became for websites.Android and iOS will continue to compete, no significant new players expected.More generic “magic” cloud and less custom-server. Like a Firebase.A chart from 10..5 years ago. Do you see the Javascript and Java rising? Python is still very popular.  GitHub language trends and the fragmenting landscape

We will see less developers, and those that are employed will be more concentrated into fewer companies. Most companies will cease their dedicated software development efforts, just as they have ceased their dedicated power supply, mainframe operators, accounting, payroll, taxes etc. The value-add of an in-house developer will plummet, as outsourced providers can develop software faster and at lower cost. HOW to train a neural network will be more important than designing one, as those designs will be pretty much vanilla. Understanding the problem and feeding the right input-output patterns will be more in demand. UI churn will be (hopefully) a thing of the past. Voice Interaction and Gestures will become very important.

Software development (the process itself) is constantly experiencing some sort of “build out”. Developers are constantly adding tools to their toolbox, frameworks, and modules. New tools are added and re-used, then tools are built on top of those tools. In 10 years most actual software development (code writing) I suspect will largely consist of assembling pre-built packages and frameworks into a working solution that fits your needs. The amount of actual code written will get smaller and smaller. Software Architecture will largely consist of making decisions on how to best integrate these modules and how to structure them in a way to minimize dependencies and impact. Software maintenance will be more about maintaining and responding to package and module changes and upgrades.

Judging by current trends: More, different, possibly better tools, platforms, libraries, etc.Maybe, just maybe, a bit more discipline. (We’ve degenerated from serious engineering to agile. Maybe we’ll see enough critical system failures to reverse the trend.)Possibly a requirement for a Professional Engineer’s license for anyone writing mission-critical or life-critical software. (This keeps coming back every time a messy system failure - like an airplane crash - is traced to a software bug.)
I wish it will be different, but it will not. Sorry but William Gibson (author) is a douche.
25 years ago I was told that “Visual Programming” will change software development, which made me smile. In ten years from now it will be the same shit. Unfortunately.

In ten years, the software will encode more visually with the use of Virtual Reality than textually as it is today. Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality will replace standard textual coding. AI will predict some steps in coding process. Delphi and Lazarus will rise again as Visual RAD programming suite with AR, VR and AI functionalities. Java, PHP and C# will be actual as well. Python will only be used for 3d fps games and hacking.

Michael Lloyd Lee has a great answer, I know this because like him I have been programming for over 20 years. I will just add, for completeness this: Microsoft’s AI is learning to write code by itself, not steal it Something to think about.

An analyst will write an atomic use case into the IDE. A tester will add appropriate test cases and the IDE will generate a completely formed and tested function. A technician on the factory floor will assemble these functions into a completed application.
It will be on peak
